channel.title: Jeremy Tinianow
channel.description: Jeremy Tinianow is a cross-disciplinary designer with a focus on bridging the gap between digital and physical.

item.title: Make
item.description:
Make

Lettering For Fun

I did this piece as a personal project for fun. The word "make" has always appealed to me as a creator.

First Sketch

First sketch.

Refinements

Making refinements.

After scanning in the sketch, I traced the outline in Illustrator and added texture in photoshop.

The Final Product

The final product.

Fin.

item.title: Frequency Fridays
item.description:
Frequency Fridays

The Brief

Arts and education non-profit the Fuse Factory contracted with me to create a set of print promotions for the 2013–2014 season of their music & tech event series Frequency Fridays. The series showcases artists who make music with technology intended for other uses.

The Concept

To communicate the nature of the event, I developed a strategy that revolved around several illustrations of music gear with "faces".

Initial concept drafts.

The first round of drafts started to feel too visually complicated. I scaled back the shadows and got rid of some strokes to simplify the visual.

Second round draft.

At this phase, I also began to play with background elements to express the varied nature and subject matter of the performances.

The Refined Concept

After a round of reviews, we decided to axe the gear-focues approach for the illustration, and experiment instead with robots. The goal was to emphasize the event's tech focus over the musical aspect.

The refined concept draft.

This approach borrowed color and pattern strategy from the previouse version, but incorporates a more tangible face.

Final Promos

The finished print pieces represent the execution of the overall strategy, using the same type of illustration on each with varying personalities for every season.

The final promotional pieces.

item.title: MAKE Puzzle
item.description:
MAKE Puzzle

The Brief

The Columbus Idea Foundry approached me to help them reach their target audience. The typical Idea Foundry member is someone who has an interest in making things, but doesn't have the tools to do so. After some discussion, we landed on the concept of using a puzzle to represent the "missing pieces" provided by the Foundry.

The Puzzle

The initial puzzle design.

I was offered use of the Foundry's CO2 laser to create the promotion, and jumped at the opportunity to play with such a high-tech piece of equipment. After designing the puzzle, I cut and etched it with the laser.

The laser cut and etched puzzle.

After cutting the puzzle, the pieces were reassembled and composed for the final promotion.

First draft of the front.

The initial design was a bit too fussy. The following draft was simplified to communicate more concisely.

The final printed promotion

The final promo piece uses four pieces of the puzzle to represent the four key areas in which the Idea Foundry helps the maker community.

item.title: Columbus Idea Foundry Brand
item.description:
Columbus Idea Foundry Brand

The Brief

Client: Columbus Idea Foundry

Working with the Foundry's leadership, our goal was to communicate the Foundry's capacity to empower individuals to create whatever they can imagine with the resources and communal knowledge available.

The Logo

As the cornerstone of the Foundry's visual identity, the new logo was the first asset to be created. In addition to clarity of communication, versatility was a crucial concern for the logo. It was important to create a mark that could be fabricated with any of the tools available at the Foundry.

Initial logo drafts.

Initial iterations focused on imagery analagous to tools, manufacturing, physics, and electricity. Departing further, we explored imagery related to the concept of ideas.

Refined drafts exploring the lightbulb.

The second round of drafts was more abstract, to avoid imagery that would be too narrowly focused upon specific creative processes. These drafts attempted to communicate ideas and community at a more conceptual level.

The final logo.

The final logo takes off on the analogy of the lightbulb as the idea, while the hexagon represents hive-like community.

The final lockup.

The logo and wordmark lockup further emphasizes idea as a core component of the Foundry's mission.

Typography

The maker community values open-source, and so does the Columbus Idea Foundry. As such, in developing the type pallete, Source Sans Pro was selected as the workhorse, supplemented by League Gothic for emphasis.

Print Collateral

Evergreen print collateral was also developed as part of the new visual identity. I worked this through from concept through creation, including some contributions to the copy.

Postcard promotion encapsulating the Idea Foundry's mission.

Signage for events.

The final style guide in it's entirety can be viewed here.
